title: Labour will ‘back second referendum that includes Boris Johnson’s deal’
text:
Labour Party shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer (R) has said Labour will back a second referendum (Picture: BBC)

Labour wants to put Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal up for a public vote.

Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer confirmed his party would back a second referendum that included the Prime Minister’s deal and an option to remain in the EU.

He told BBC’s Andrew Marr Show: ‘Whatever deal gets through, it should be subject to a referendum.

‘We have already voted, I think, three times as a party for a second referendum with a three-line whip behind it.

‘What we are trying to achieve is, this deal in particular but any deal is put up against remain in a referendum.’

Sir Keir Starmer suggested Labour was prepared to vote through the P~M’s Brexit deal if it meant securing a second referendum (Picture: BBC)

Sir Keir added: ‘The spirit of this is very, very clear and we actually offered this to Theresa May.

‘We said that we don’t think your deal is very good, but if it’s up against the safeguard of being able to remain, then we will allow it to proceed in that way.’

Sir Keir admitted setting up a new vote would not be straight forward and would need ‘detailed legislation’ and up to five months of preparation.

He added it would probably be best if a broad cross-party coalition of backbench MPs tabled an amendment for a second referendum.

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab criticised Labour’s plans for a new referendum (Picture: BBC)

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, who was appearing alongside Sir Keir on the Marr Show, slammed the Labour party for backing a new vote and accused it of reversing its manifesto pledge to carry out the result of the 2016 referendum.

He said he was hoping to get the Prime Minister’s Brexit deal through next week, adding: ‘Many of your viewers at home will be astonished.

‘We’ve actually secured a deal with the EU.

‘A lot of people said the Prime Minister couldn’t do that. He’s got that deal. We seem to have the numbers in the House of Commons.’

Mr Johnson was forced to request a delay from the EU when the Letwin amendment passed in the House of Commons on Saturday.

He delayed the vote on his Brexit deal as a result.
